handDesc.p: Halantas. Final M is derived from the shape of a classical ma with an upward extension that bends right and then up again, but is now stylised into a circle with a tail on top that bends right and then up. The circle part is much like an anusvāra. E.g. l3 °litānāM. Final N is likewise based on na, but has only a horseshoe shape at the bottom, with the upward tail bending right, up, then right again. E.g. l10 māsāN. Final T is formed in the same way. A clear example is l17 avarddhayaT; cchinaT in l15 is unclear at the top and may be cchinata, just like harata for haraT earlier in the same line.
Original punctuation marks are long, straight and plain verticals. This sign is doubled after l27 ca. The one after l14-15 āharata is unclear and may in fact consist of three short verticals.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is a fairly large circle well above the headline, atop or to the right of the consonant to which it belongs, occasionally atop the next character, probably only when displaced by a descender, e.g. the first anusvāra of l10 saptatriṁśataṁ is above śa, because stra in the previous line prevents it from being closer to tri. Occasionally it is also lowered to or below headline height, e.g. l1 Ekānnaviṁśatin, where jo and vi in the previous line (themselves pushed downward by descenders further above) prevent its regular placement. Rare jha occurs (as a subscript consonant) in l26 jhaṭiti.

app.note: The first three characters of this word are closely spaced, and the vowel of hā is added on top of the consonant rather than as an extension of the top to the right. Some level of correction is probably involved here. Possibly, svāmihāsena or svāmahāsena was first engraved and then corrected to the expected text; or, in a more simple scenarion, the ā of hā was omitted and added later on.
Pre-modern correction may be present here. The superfluous ā mātrās may have been deleted, and it is also possible that tadānujo was first engraved and then corrected into the expected text.
Possibly a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition.
The scanned photo is not clear enough for me to tell whether the expected ā is present, but I suspect a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition.
Most of this line is unclear to wholly illegible in the scanned photo; but Sankaranarayanan only marks naṁdaya as unclear.

Based on the scanned photo, I am not entirely sure this is corrected text. Sankaranarayanan in a footnote anchored after ca|| at the beginning of this line says, These 7 letters are engraved on an erasure. I see no trace of erasure at that point, nor any clear way of identifying which 7 letters the note may refer to. However, he also prints the seven characters of this locus in square brackets (normally signifying unclear). These characters are quite clearly legible, but seem to be surrounded with a fair amount of noise and to have less neat lines. I thus assume that Sankaranarayanan's note refers to this locus, and that he was in a position to confidently discern vestiges of deleted writing underneath these.
The double l is probably a typo in Sankaranarayanan's edition, and the reason he emends is only the anusvāra.

div.p: Sankaranarayanan gives the metre of stanza 4 as indravaṁśā, in which case the first quarter should begin with a short syllable.

Reported in 38A/1960-612 with discussion at 14>. Edited (from photos, impressions and the original) by S. Sankaranarayanan (95-1042), with photographs of the plates and seal (no translation). The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Sankaranarayanan's text with his photos.The photos, as printed, are not very clear and scanning has not improved them. Many details should ideally be checked against a better facsimile. Sankaranarayanan's edition has many typographic mistakes; only major ones are shown in the apparatus here and others are silently assumed to have been correctly read by Sankaranarayanan.
